Overview of Projects

Programming based projects during my years as a physics graduate student.

My Ph.D. analysis required computational and programming skills that I wanted to acquire. In order to quickly learn, I started working on often physics-inspired projects during my spare time, and eventually developed new passion. The purpose of this site is to organize all my side-projects for my own satisfaction, and for any one else that may find the projects interesting. The programming language of choice is typically C++ (not that it matters, but C++ is common in my field), and I make heavy use of the bare-bones multimedia library SFML in addition to CERN's scientific framework ROOT for statistical tools, e.g. plotting, fit functions, and probability distributions. All algorithms including visualization and user-interaction are my own work unless explicitly stated otherwise. While other higher level tools exist, I chose to do it this way for my own education and curiosity. The most recent posts are below, and the full list may be found here.

15 Jun 2018

Scenic screen saver

Includes simulated ropes, a sunset/sunrise model, and Perlin coherent noise

20 May 2018

Tree Fractal II

A significant upgrade to the previous tree fractal post including a random tree generator

12 May 2018

Fractal Ferns

Generating fractal ferns using iterated function systems

20 Mar 2018

Convex Hulls

An algorithm to find the perimeter of a data set, and includes convex polygon overlap detection

04 Jan 2018

Word Search

An interactive word search generator/game

28 Aug 2017

Mona Lisa from Triangles?

A hill climbing method to mimic an input image with randomly generated triangles

27 Jul 2017

Double Pendulum

Simulating the double pendulum using RK4

10 May 2017

Koch Snowflake

A variation of the Koch snowflake

05 Feb 2017

Square Art

Creating interesting pattens with squares

18 Jul 2016

Snake

An interactive snake game
